content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-267-25-A |Item_parent=Disorders of acid-base balance and fluid-electrolyte disorders |Item_parent_short=Disorders of acid-base balance and fluid and electrolyte disorders |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the symptoms of severe hyponatremia |Description=Know the signs of moderate and severe hyponatremia. |Rubric=Identification of the emergency |Contributors=P Rieu; B Moulin; M Flamant |Order=25}} *Severe hyponatremia = < 120 mmol/L. *Clinical signs (Table 7): **non-specific and therefore not very suggestive, **correlated with the severity of the hyponatremia and its rapid onset. Table 7: Symptoms of hyponatraemia (ERBP classification 2014). {| class="wikitable" |Hyponatremia with moderately severe symptoms |Hyponatremia with severe symptoms |- |- Nausea (without vomiting) - Confusion - Headache |- Vomiting - Cardiorespiratory distress - Sleepiness (abnormal and profound) - Comitiality - Consciousness disorders - Coma (Glasgow ≤ 8) |}

question.title: What is a symptom of severe hyponatremia?

option_a.title: Vomiting
option_a.description: One of the symptoms of hyponatremia

option_b.title: Headache
option_b.description: A symptom that can be present in hyponatremia

option_d.title: Nausea
option_d.description: A symptom that can be present in mild hyponatremia
